title: Datascience2 - TextMining
text:
Daten laden

d_raw <- 
  data_read("C:/Users/marku/Desktop/GermEval-2018-Data-master/germeval2018.training.txt",
         header = FALSE)

Warning in data.table::fread(input = path, ...): Found and resolved improper
quoting out-of-sample. First healed line 111: <<"Edel sei der Mensch, hilfreich
und gut" - Nicht eine dieser Charaktereigenschaften kann Merkel fÃ¼r sich
beanspruchen. OTHER OTHER>>. If the fields are not quoted (e.g. field separator
does not appear within any field), try quote="" to avoid this warning.



names(d_raw) <- c("text", "c1", "c2")


d_raw %>% 
  count(c1)

       c1    n
1 OFFENSE 1688
2   OTHER 3321



d_raw %>% 
  count(c2)

         c2    n
1     ABUSE 1022
2    INSULT  595
3     OTHER 3321
4 PROFANITY   71



d_raw %>% 
  filter(c1 == "OTHER", c2 == "OTHER") %>% 
  nrow() / nrow(d_raw)

[1] 0.6630066



d_raw %>% 
  filter(c1 != "OTHER", c2 != "OTHER") %>% 
  nrow() / nrow(d_raw)

[1] 0.3369934



d1 <-
  d_raw %>% 
  mutate(id = as.character(1:nrow(.)))

title: Datascience2 - TextMining
text:
TextlÃ¤nge

d2 <-
  d1 %>% 
  mutate(text_length = str_length(text))

head(d2)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          text
1                                                                                                                                                                                @corinnamilborn Liebe Corinna, wir wÃ¼rden dich gerne als Moderatorin fÃ¼r uns gewinnen! WÃ¤rst du begeisterbar?
2                                                                                                                                               @Martin28a Sie haben ja auch Recht. Unser Tweet war etwas missverstÃ¤ndlich. Dass das BVerfG Sachleistungen nicht ausschlieÃŸt, kritisieren wir.
3                                                                                                                                                                                                                        @ahrens_theo frÃ¶hlicher gruÃŸ aus der schÃ¶nsten stadt der welt theo âš“ï¸
4                                                                                                                                                 @dushanwegner Amis hÃ¤tten alles und jeden gewÃ¤hlt...nur Hillary wollten sie nicht und eine Fortsetzung von Obama-Politik erst recht nicht..!
5                                                                                                                                                     @spdde kein verlÃ¤ÃŸlicher Verhandlungspartner. Nachkarteln nach den SondierzngsgesprÃ¤chen - schickt diese StÃ¼mper #SPD in die Versenkung.
6 @Dirki_M Ja, aber wo widersprechen die Zahlen denn denen, die im von uns verlinkten Artikel stehen? In unserem Tweet geht es rein um subs. GeschÃ¼tzte. 2017 ist der gesamte Familiennachzug im Vergleich zu 2016 - die Zahlen, die Hr. Brandner bemÃ¼ht - Ã¼brigens leicht rÃ¼cklÃ¤ufig gewesen.
       c1     c2 id text_length
1   OTHER  OTHER  1         109
2   OTHER  OTHER  2         142
3   OTHER  OTHER  3          69
4   OTHER  OTHER  4         140
5 OFFENSE INSULT  5         136
6   OTHER  OTHER  6         284

title: Datascience2 - TextMining
text:
Sentimentanalyse

sentiws <- read_csv("https://osf.io/x89wq/?action=download")

Rows: 3468 Columns: 4
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (3): neg_pos, word, inflections
dbl (1): value

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.



d2_long <-
  d2 %>% 
  unnest_tokens(input = text, output = token)

head(d2_long)

     c1    c2 id text_length          token
1 OTHER OTHER  1         109 corinnamilborn
2 OTHER OTHER  1         109          liebe
3 OTHER OTHER  1         109        corinna
4 OTHER OTHER  1         109            wir
5 OTHER OTHER  1         109         wÃ¼rden
6 OTHER OTHER  1         109           dich



d2_long_senti <- 
  d2_long %>%  
  inner_join(sentiws %>% select(-inflections), by = c("token" = "word"))

head(d2_long)

     c1    c2 id text_length          token
1 OTHER OTHER  1         109 corinnamilborn
2 OTHER OTHER  1         109          liebe
3 OTHER OTHER  1         109        corinna
4 OTHER OTHER  1         109            wir
5 OTHER OTHER  1         109         wÃ¼rden
6 OTHER OTHER  1         109           dich



d2_sentis <-
  d2_long_senti %>% 
  group_by(id, neg_pos) %>% 
  summarise(senti_avg = mean(value))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'id'. You can override using the `.groups`
argument.

head(d2_sentis)

# A tibble: 6 Ã— 3
# Groups:   id [6]
  id    neg_pos senti_avg
  <chr> <chr>       <dbl>
1 1     pos        0.004 
2 1012  neg       -0.209 
3 1013  neg       -0.042 
4 1015  neg       -0.0048
5 1021  pos        0.0845
6 1024  neg       -0.479 



d2_sentis_wide <-
  d2_sentis %>% 
  pivot_wider(names_from = "neg_pos", values_from = "senti_avg")

d2_sentis_wide %>% head()

# A tibble: 6 Ã— 3
# Groups:   id [6]
  id        pos     neg
  <chr>   <dbl>   <dbl>
1 1      0.004  NA     
2 1012  NA      -0.209 
3 1013  NA      -0.042 
4 1015  NA      -0.0048
5 1021   0.0845 NA     
6 1024   0.004  -0.479 



d3 <-
  d2 %>% 
  full_join(d2_sentis_wide)

Joining, by = "id"

head(d3)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          text
1                                                                                                                                                                                @corinnamilborn Liebe Corinna, wir wÃ¼rden dich gerne als Moderatorin fÃ¼r uns gewinnen! WÃ¤rst du begeisterbar?
2                                                                                                                                               @Martin28a Sie haben ja auch Recht. Unser Tweet war etwas missverstÃ¤ndlich. Dass das BVerfG Sachleistungen nicht ausschlieÃŸt, kritisieren wir.
3                                                                                                                                                                                                                        @ahrens_theo frÃ¶hlicher gruÃŸ aus der schÃ¶nsten stadt der welt theo âš“ï¸
4                                                                                                                                                 @dushanwegner Amis hÃ¤tten alles und jeden gewÃ¤hlt...nur Hillary wollten sie nicht und eine Fortsetzung von Obama-Politik erst recht nicht..!
5                                                                                                                                                     @spdde kein verlÃ¤ÃŸlicher Verhandlungspartner. Nachkarteln nach den SondierzngsgesprÃ¤chen - schickt diese StÃ¼mper #SPD in die Versenkung.
6 @Dirki_M Ja, aber wo widersprechen die Zahlen denn denen, die im von uns verlinkten Artikel stehen? In unserem Tweet geht es rein um subs. GeschÃ¼tzte. 2017 ist der gesamte Familiennachzug im Vergleich zu 2016 - die Zahlen, die Hr. Brandner bemÃ¼ht - Ã¼brigens leicht rÃ¼cklÃ¤ufig gewesen.
       c1     c2 id text_length   pos     neg
1   OTHER  OTHER  1         109 0.004      NA
2   OTHER  OTHER  2         142    NA -0.3466
3   OTHER  OTHER  3          69    NA      NA
4   OTHER  OTHER  4         140    NA      NA
5 OFFENSE INSULT  5         136    NA      NA
6   OTHER  OTHER  6         284 0.004 -0.2042

title: Datascience2 - TextMining
text:
Profanities

profanities1 <- data_read("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/LDNOOBW/List-of-Dirty-Naughty-Obscene-and-Otherwise-Bad-Words/master/de", format = ",", header = FALSE)

Reading data...


Preparing data... Almost there!



profanities2 <- 
  schimpfwoerter %>% 
  mutate_all(str_to_lower) %>% 
  rename(V1 = "word")


profanities <-
  profanities1 %>% 
  bind_rows(profanities2) %>% 
  distinct()

nrow(profanities)

[1] 6208


Distinct Funktion beseitigt die doppelten SchimpfwÃ¶rter

d_profanity <- 
d2_long %>% 
  select(id, token) %>% 
  mutate(profanity = token %in% profanities$word)


d_profanity %>% 
  count(profanity)

  profanity      n
1     FALSE 100217



d_profanity2 <-
  d_profanity %>% 
  group_by(id) %>% 
  summarise(profanity_n = sum(profanity))

head(d_profanity2)

# A tibble: 6 Ã— 2
  id    profanity_n
  <chr>       <int>
1 1               0
2 10              0
3 100             0
4 1000            0
5 1001            0
6 1002            0



d_main <-
  d3 %>% 
  full_join(d_profanity2)

Joining, by = "id"

title: Datascience2 - TextMining
text:
Emojis

emj <- emoji(list_emoji(), pad = FALSE)

head(emj)

[1] "ğŸ˜„" "ğŸ˜ƒ" "ğŸ˜€" "ğŸ˜Š" "â˜ºï¸"  "ğŸ˜‰"



wild_emojis <- 
  c(
    emoji(find_emoji("gun")),
    emoji(find_emoji("bomb")),
    emoji(find_emoji("fist")),
    emoji(find_emoji("knife"))[1],
    emoji(find_emoji("ambulance")),
    emoji(find_emoji("fist")),
    emoji(find_emoji("skull")),
    "â˜ ï¸",     "ğŸ—‘",       "ğŸ˜ ",    "ğŸ‘¹",    "ğŸ’©" ,
    "ğŸ–•",    "ğŸ‘ï¸",
    emoji(find_emoji("middle finger")),    "ğŸ˜¡",    "ğŸ¤¢",    "ğŸ¤®",  
    "ğŸ˜–",    "ğŸ˜£",    "ğŸ˜©",    "ğŸ˜¨",    "ğŸ˜",    "ğŸ˜³",    "ğŸ˜¬",    "ğŸ˜±",    "ğŸ˜µ",
       "ğŸ˜¤",    "ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸",    "ğŸ¤¦â€"
  )


wild_emojis_df <-
  tibble(emoji = wild_emojis)

save(wild_emojis_df, file = "C:/Users/marku/Desktop/wild_emojis.RData")

title: Datascience2 - TextMining
text:
Data Split

d_split <- initial_split(d1, strata = c1)

d_train <- training(d_split)
d_test <- testing(d_split)

title: Datascience2 - TextMining
text:
Rezept 1

rec1 <- recipe(c1 ~ ., data = select(d_train, text, c1, id)) %>%
  update_role(id, new_role = "id") %>%
  step_tokenize(text) %>%
  step_stopwords(text, language = "de", stopword_source = "snowball") %>%
  step_stem(text) %>%
  step_tokenfilter(text, max_tokens = 1e2) %>%
  step_tfidf(text) %>%
  step_normalize(all_numeric_predictors())

rec1

Recipe

Inputs:

      role #variables
        id          1
   outcome          1
 predictor          1

Operations:

Tokenization for text
Stop word removal for text
Stemming for text
Text filtering for text
Term frequency-inverse document frequency with text
Centering and scaling for all_numeric_predictors()



rec1_prep <- prep(rec1)


rec1_bake <- bake(rec1_prep, new_data = NULL)

head(rec1_bake)

# A tibble: 6 Ã— 102
  id    c1      tfidf_text__macmik tfidf_text_2 tfidf_text_ab tfidf_text_afd
  <fct> <fct>                <dbl>        <dbl>         <dbl>          <dbl>
1 7     OFFENSE             -0.151       -0.104        -0.103         -0.155
2 10    OFFENSE             -0.151       -0.104        -0.103         -0.155
3 12    OFFENSE             -0.151       -0.104        -0.103         -0.155
4 17    OFFENSE             -0.151       -0.104        -0.103         -0.155
5 27    OFFENSE             -0.151       -0.104        -0.103         -0.155
6 42    OFFENSE             -0.151       -0.104        -0.103         -0.155
# â€¦ with 96 more variables: tfidf_text_amp <dbl>, tfidf_text_anna_iina <dbl>,
#   tfidf_text_athinamala <dbl>, tfidf_text_beim <dbl>,
#   tfidf_text_besser <dbl>, tfidf_text_bild <dbl>, tfidf_text_cdu <dbl>,
#   tfidf_text_charlie_silv <dbl>, tfidf_text_d <dbl>, tfidf_text_dafÃ¼r <dbl>,
#   tfidf_text_dank <dbl>, tfidf_text_dass <dbl>, tfidf_text_deutsch <dbl>,
#   tfidf_text_deutschen <dbl>, tfidf_text_deutschland <dbl>,
#   tfidf_text_dumm <dbl>, tfidf_text_eigentlich <dbl>, â€¦

title: Datascience2 - TextMining
text:
Model 1

nb_spec <- naive_Bayes() %>%
  set_mode("classification") %>%
  set_engine("naivebayes")

nb_spec

Naive Bayes Model Specification (classification)

Computational engine: naivebayes 



set.seed(13)
cv_folds <- vfold_cv(d_train)

title: Datascience2 - TextMining
text:
workflow 1

wf1 <- workflow() %>%
  add_recipe(rec1) %>%
  add_model(nb_spec)

wf1

â•â• Workflow â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
Preprocessor: Recipe
Model: naive_Bayes()

â”€â”€ Preprocessor â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
6 Recipe Steps

â€¢ step_tokenize()
â€¢ step_stopwords()
â€¢ step_stem()
â€¢ step_tokenfilter()
â€¢ step_tfidf()
â€¢ step_normalize()

â”€â”€ Model â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Naive Bayes Model Specification (classification)

Computational engine: naivebayes 



Fit

fit1 <- fit_resamples(wf1, cv_folds, control = control_resamples(save_pred = TRUE))

Warning: Paket 'stopwords' wurde unter R Version 4.2.2 erstellt




Performance

wf1_performance <- collect_metrics(fit1)

wf1_performance

# A tibble: 2 Ã— 6
  .metric  .estimator  mean     n std_err .config             
  <chr>    <chr>      <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>               
1 accuracy binary     0.663    10 0.00974 Preprocessor1_Model1
2 roc_auc  binary     0.605    10 0.00583 Preprocessor1_Model1



wf_preds <- collect_predictions(fit1)

wf_preds %>%
  group_by(id) %>%
  roc_curve(truth = c1, .pred_OFFENSE) %>%
  autoplot()

title: Datascience2 - TextMining
text:
Nullmodell

null_classification <- parsnip::null_model() %>%
  set_engine("parsnip") %>%
  set_mode("classification")


Resampling

null_rs <- workflow() %>%
  add_recipe(rec1) %>%
  add_model(null_classification) %>%
  fit_resamples(cv_folds)



Performance

null_rs %>%
  collect_metrics()

# A tibble: 2 Ã— 6
  .metric  .estimator  mean     n std_err .config             
  <chr>    <chr>      <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>               
1 accuracy binary     0.663    10 0.00865 Preprocessor1_Model1
2 roc_auc  binary     0.5      10 0       Preprocessor1_Model1

show_best(null_rs)

Warning: No value of `metric` was given; metric 'roc_auc' will be used.


# A tibble: 1 Ã— 6
  .metric .estimator  mean     n std_err .config             
  <chr>   <chr>      <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>               
1 roc_auc binary       0.5    10       0 Preprocessor1_Model1

title: Datascience2 - TextMining
text:
Workflow 2

doParallel::registerDoParallel()

cores <- parallel::detectCores(logical = TRUE)

lasso_spec <- logistic_reg(penalty = tune(), mixture = 1) %>%
  set_mode("classification") %>%
  set_engine("glmnet", num.threads = cores)

lasso_spec

Logistic Regression Model Specification (classification)

Main Arguments:
  penalty = tune()
  mixture = 1

Engine-Specific Arguments:
  num.threads = cores

Computational engine: glmnet 



lambda_grid <- grid_regular(penalty(), levels = 30)


wf2 <- workflow() %>%
  add_recipe(rec1) %>%
  add_model(lasso_spec)

wf2

â•â• Workflow â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
Preprocessor: Recipe
Model: logistic_reg()

Logistic Regression Model Specification (classification)

Main Arguments:
  penalty = tune()
  mixture = 1

Engine-Specific Arguments:
  num.threads = cores

Computational engine: glmnet 



Tune & Fit

set.seed(2246)

tic()

fit2 <- tune_grid(wf2, cv_folds, grid = lambda_grid, control = control_resamples(save_pred = TRUE))

toc()
